revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=March 2007}} The '''72nd Infantry Division''' ({{lang-fr|72e Division d'Infanterie, 72e DI}}) was a [[French Army]] formation during [[World War I]].
The division was a reserve formation of the French Army, based at [[Verdun]]. It was mobilised on 2 August 1914. On mobilisation it commanded the 351st, 362nd, 364th, 365th, and 366th Infantry Regiments and the 56th and 59th Battalions of Chasseurs à Pied. It formed part of the garrison of the Verdun fortress and was subordinated to the French 3rd Army.
The division remained in the Verdun region until August 1916 (during which it participated in the [[Battle of Verdun]]), when it was then moved north, where it then participated in the [[Battle of the Somme]]. In 1918 the division took part in the [[Second Battle of the Marne]].
At the end of the war, only the 365th Infantry Regiment of the original force remained with the division, the other units having been posted away, amalgamated, or disbanded. In addition to this, the 1st Mixed Regiment of Zouaves and Tirailleurs, and the 31st Territorial Infantry Regiment formed part of the division.
At various times, it was part of the [[First Army (France)|French First Army]], [[Second Army (France)|French Second Army]], [[Third Army (France)|French Third Army]], [[Fourth Army (France)|French Fourth Army]], [[Fifth Army (France)|French Fifth Army]], [[Sixth Army (France)|French Sixth Army]], [[Seventh Army (France)|French Seventh Army]], [[Tenth Army (France)|French Tenth Army]], Army of the Lorraine, GQGA and the Fortified Region of Verdun. {{Template:French Army Divisions}} [[Category:Infantry divisions of France]] [[Category:French World War I divisions|Infantry Division, 72nd]] [[Category:Military units and formations established in 1914]] [[Category:1914 establishments in France]]
{{europe-mil-stub}}

{{Infobox song | name = A Luta é Alegria | cover = A Luta É Alegria.JPG | alt = | border = yes | type = single | artist = Homens da Luta | album = | released = 2011 | format = [[CD single]] | recorded = 2011 | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Folk music|Folk]], [[protest song]] | length = {{duration|m=2|s=52}} | label = | writer = Vasco Duarte, Jel | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = | misc = {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{Flagicon|Portugal}} "A luta é alegria" | image = | caption = | year = 2011 | country = Portugal | artist = [[Homens da Luta]] | as = | with = | language = Portuguese | composer = Vasco Duarte | lyricist = Jel | place = | points = | place_semi = 18th | points_semi = 22 | lyrics = | prev = Há dias assim | prev_link = Há dias assim | next = Vida minha | next_link = Vida minha }} }} "'''A luta é alegria'''" (''The struggle is joy'') was the [[Portugal|Portuguese]] entry for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2011]] in [[Germany]], performed by [[Homens da Luta]]. It was chosen for Eurovision by winning the [[Portugal in the Eurovision Song Contest 2011|Festival da Canção 2011]] on 5 March 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvi24.iol.pt/musica/musica/homens-da-luta/1151639-4060.html |title=IOL Música - Homens da Luta lançam álbum em formato mp3 |publisher=Tvi24.iol.pt |date=2010-03-31 |accessdate=2011-09-15}} However, it did not progress beyond the semi-final. ==Background== ===Production history=== "A luta é alegria" was composed by Vasco Duarte, while the lyrics were written by Jel. The song incorporates [[Music of Portugal|folk music]] style. ===Song meaning=== The song refers to the struggle that the people must endure to have their voices heard, by shouting and celebrating on the street. It calls for the union of the people, and to sing against [[Reactionary|reaction]].{{cite web|url=http://eurovisiontimes.wordpress.com/esc-2011/participants/portugal-homens-da-luta-a-luta-e-alegria/ |title=Portugal: Homens Da Luta – A Luta é Alegria « The Eurovision Times |publisher=Eurovisiontimes.wordpress.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-15}} ==The performers== Homens da Luta (Men of the Struggle) is a collective of traditional Portuguese music of an interventionist style. Inspired by the musical universe of the period after [[Carnation Revolution|April 25, 1974]], the band is led by the unavoidable Neto and Falâncio (brothers Nuno "Jel" and Vasco Duarte), and first appeared on TV five years ago in a comedy show. However, soon they were travelling through the cities, towns, and villages of Portugal, spreading their music and their sense of humour. They bring "A Luta É Alegria (The Struggle is Joy)" to the 2011 Eurovision Song Contest, inspired by the tradition of collective singing, which was so fashionable in Portugal in the late 1970s.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/year/participant-profile/?song=25913 |title=Eurovision: Participant profile |publisher=Eurovision.tv |date= |accessdate=2011-09-15}} ==Charts== {| class="wikitable" |- !align="left"|Chart !align="left"|Peak
position |- |align="left"|Albania ([[Tekste Shqip]]) | style="text-align:center;"|13 |- |align="left"|Portugal ([[Nielsen SoundScan|Nielsen]]){{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/fullscreen/55712672?access_key=key-1091jq3r9fvekx54eblt |title=Portugal Singles Chart - Nielsen SoundScan |publisher=Scribd.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-15}} | style="text-align:center;"|4 |} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 2011}} {{Portugal in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{DEFAULTSORT:A Luta E Alegria}} [[Category:2011 songs]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 2011]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of Portugal]] {{Portugal-stub}} {{2010s-single-stub}}
