'''Study Group''' is a global company that prepares international students for university degree programmes, teaches high school education, and teaches English language courses. Study Group owns and operates colleges and also partners with more than 50 universities across the UK, Europe, North America and Australasia. In 2014, Study Group enrolled more than 63,000 students from 170 countries. [[Image:BrightonStudyCen1.JPG|thumb|250px|Study Group's new study centre and UK office in the [[New England Quarter]], Brighton.]] The company's trading names include '''Embassy''' (formerly named Embassy CES), [[Bellerbys College]] in the UK and [[Martin College]] in Australia. Study Group also operates '''International Study Centres''' within UK, European, US, Canadian and Australian universities. It has offices in [[London]] and [[Brighton]], England, [[New York City]], USA and [[Sydney]], Australia and also operates in Canada and New Zealand, China and Singapore. {{cite web |url=http://www.studygroup.com/global-locations|publisher=Study Group|title=Global Locations|accessdate=2009-11-26}} ==History== The company dates the origin of Study Group from the Embassy language school in [[Hastings]], England, acquired by businessmen Andrew Colin and Duncan Greenland in 1989. A second language school was opened in [[Hove]] shortly after. Colin had previously acquired Bellerbys College, a [[Sixth form college|sixth-form college]] for international students. In 1994 the company British Study Group was formed incorporating the two businesses and adding a third shareholder/director John Collyer. In 1996, 40% of the business was acquired by the [[Daily Mail and General Trust|Daily Mail Group]],[http://www.dmgt.co.uk/mediacentre/newsreleases/19981210/3165/ Daily Mail Group Press release] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011151737/http://www.dmgt.co.uk/mediacentre/newsreleases/19981210/3165/ |date=2008-10-11 }} Preliminary unaudited consolidated results from Thursday 10 December 1998; mentions Study Group becoming a subsidiary. becoming Study Group International and expanding into the US and Australia.[http://www.dmgt.co.uk/mediacentre/newsreleases/19971211/3145/ Another Daily Mail Group press release] Preliminary unaudited consolidated results from Thursday 11 December 1997; mentions expansion into US and Australia.[http://www.hothousemedia.com/ltm/ltmbackissues/feb05web/feb05specreport.htm Special Report: The Evolution of ELC] from Language Travel Magazine. See paragraph headed 'Study Group' for details of acquisition strategy. Later, in 1999, the Daily Mail Group became the 100% owner of Study Group, paying an estimated UK£44 million.[http://www.hothousemedia.com/ltm/ltmbackissues/jun07web/jun07specreport.htm Language Travel Magazine] Special Report: Industry Entrepreneurs, June 2007, paragraph titled 'Alternative angles and corporate investment' As well as expanding the UK and Australian operations, Study Group acquired the Center for English Studies (CES) chain of language schools in the USA and Canada, adding [[Boston]], [[Fort Lauderdale]], [[Los Angeles]], [[New York City|New York]], [[San Diego]], [[San Francisco]], [[Seattle]] and [[Vancouver]] to their fold. Embassy became Embassy CES, and then Embassy English. In 2006 Study Group was acquired by Australian [[private equity]] company Champ, having been sold by Daily Mail Group for A$176.4 million.[http://www.champmbo.com/html/portfolio_sgi.html Champ website - portfolio page] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080720011818/http://www.champmbo.com/html/portfolio_sgi.html |date=2008-07-20 }}[http://www.freshfields.com/sector/comms-media/news/Pressrelease.asp?newsitem=938 Press release] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927223254/http://www.freshfields.com/sector/comms-media/news/Pressrelease.asp?newsitem=938 |date=2007-09-27 }} from international law firm Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer, advisors on the sale. In 2007, the Brighton school and UK head office moved to purpose-built premises in the [[New England Quarter]], next to [[Brighton station]],[http://www.embassyenglish.com/schools/england/brighton Embassy website Brighton location] Embassy Brighton[http://www.studygroup.com/corporate/english/news_2006/brighton_centre_1.asp Study Group.com corporate website] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071008184347/http://www.studygroup.com/corporate/english/news_2006/brighton_centre_1.asp |date=2007-10-08 }} New Brighton Study Centre Ahead of Schedule.[http://www.new-england-quarter.co.uk/commercial.htm New England Quarter official site] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071006133545/http://www.new-england-quarter.co.uk/commercial.htm |date=2007-10-06 }} Short description of the Quarter's commercial uses. costing an estimated UK£28 million.[http://www.hothousemedia.com/ltm/ltmbackissues/may07web/may07news.htm Language Travel Magazine] New Buildings for British ELT On July 1, 2010, Providence Equity Partners took ownership of Study Group for $660 million Australian dollars. ==International Study Centres== In the [[United Kingdom]], Study Group has entered into agreements with a number of universities, whereby students are taught at an "International Study Centre" by Study Group staff on the university's premises. These "foundation" courses are designed to prepare students for a regular undergraduate and postgraduate degree courses. The company website lists such arrangements at the following 'host' universities: [[Heriot-Watt University|Heriot-Watt]] (Edinburgh), [[Keele University|Keele]], [[Kingston University|Kingston]], [[University of Huddersfield|Huddersfield]], [[Lancaster University|Lancaster]], [[University of Leicester|Leicester]], [[University of Lincoln|Lincoln]], [[Liverpool John Moores University|Liverpool John Moores]], [[University of Strathclyde|Strathclyde]] (Glasgow), [[University of Surrey|Surrey]], and the [[University of Sussex|Sussex]]. The group has also had centres at [[University of Wales, Newport]]{{cite web |url=http://www.studygroup.com/isc/wales/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140709162606/http://www.studygroup.com/isc/wales/ |archivedate=2014-07-09 |df= }} and the [[University of Stirling]]{{cite web |url=http://www.studygroup.com/isc/stirling/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140605215312/http://www.studygroup.com/isc/stirling/ |archivedate=2014-06-05 |df= }} which have closed. Under these arrangements, the Study Group programmes are validated by the host university and are marketed alongside the host university's own degree courses. On each university's website, information about Study Group courses are contained on Study Group web pages with the identical appearance to the university's own web pages. Brighton-based Study Group established one of the first of these arrangements at the nearby [[University of Sussex]].http://www.dmgt.co.uk/mediacentre/newsreleases/20051117/3355/ These partnerships are attractive to UK universities as they provide a way of increasing numbers of overseas students, whose fee income is important. Equally, they attract criticism{{cite news |title=International Study saga continues |url=http://www.ussu.info/files/minisites/1690/2005-6t2%20Badger1.pdf |format=PDF |newspaper=The Badger |date=January 9, 2006 |location=University of Sussex |page=3 }}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} on the basis that students do not expect a British university course to be provided by a commercial company, that the course quality is not accredited within the university system,{{cite web |url=http://www.keeleucu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2010/04/Special-Newsletter-March-2009.pdf |format=PDF|title=Privatisation at Keele|date=March 2009|publisher=[[University and College Union]]|location=Keele}} and that staff transferred to Study Group employment may lose the pay and pension benefits associated with university employment.{{cite web |url=https://www.ucu.org.uk/media/pdf/l/l/privatecospathwayprovision.pdf |format=PDF|title=International students and pathway provision: The case against the private sector|date=October 2009|publisher=[[University and College Union]]}} Study Group has made the same arrangements with a number of United States universities, which have received similar comments. The company website lists such arrangements at the following universities: [[James Madison University|JMU]], [[Long Island University|LIU Post]], [[Roosevelt University|Roosevelt]], [[University of Maine|UMaine]], [[University of Vermont|Vermont]], [[Widener University|Widener]].{{cite news |title=Problem: Foreign Students. Solution: Corporate Partner.|url=http://chronicle.com/article/Problem-Foreign-Students/26596 |newspaper=Chronicle of Higher Education|date=September 5, 2008|author=Karin Fischer|registration=yes}} Full article available at [http://livingininterestingtimes.wordpress.com/2008/09/27/outsourcing-teaching/] ==Embassy English== As of October 2017, Embassy English has 15 year-round schools[http://www.embassyenglish.com/schools Embassy English site: Schools] in: * USA: [[New York City|New York]], [[Boston]], [[San Diego]], [[San Francisco]] * UK: [[London]], [[Brighton]], [[Cambridge]], [[Hastings]], [[Oxford]] * Australia: [[Sydney]], [[Brisbane]], [[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast]], [[Melbourne]] * New Zealand: [[Auckland]] * Canada: [[Toronto]] Approximately 36,000 students per year study with Embassy English.In 2004. [http://www.hothousemedia.com/ltm/ltmbackissues/feb05web/feb05specreport.htm Special Report the Evolution of ELC] from Language Travel Magazine - see paragraph titled 'Study Group'. Embassy English opened its first purpose-built school designed by Watkins Grey Associates LLP[http://www.wgi.co.uk/wgiEduSGC.html Watkins Grey Associates website] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009131856/http://www.wgi.co.uk/wgiEduSGC.html |date=2007-10-09 }} Overview of build project, with photos.[http://www.studygroup.com/corporate/english/news_2004/greenwich_ukconstruction.pdf PDF from UK Construction Magazine] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071008184604/http://www.studygroup.com/corporate/english/news_2004/greenwich_ukconstruction.pdf |date=2007-10-08 }} (hosted on Studygroup corporate site) describing the building's features. on a site in [[Greenwich]]/[[Deptford]], [[London]], sharing premises with sister company Bellerbys College. Residential accommodation was also built in partnership with the [[University of Greenwich]][http://www.jarvis-uk.com/jarvisplc/media/releases/pr2003/2003-02-11/ Press release from the builders, Jarvis PLC] Greenwich development will deliver new student digs 11 February 2003. ==Embassy Summer== In addition to the year-round schools, Embassy English operate summer schools at over 30 locations across the UK and North America as "Embassy Summer".[http://www.embassysummer.com Embassy Summer website] The Embassy Summer school programme operates at the site of various university and college partners, in addition to several of the year-round Embassy centres.
A range of activities are offered under the Embassy Summer Plus[https://archive.is/20150104160946/http://www.embassysummer.com/summerplus Embassy Summer Plus page] and Embassy Summer Academy[http://www.embassyacademy.com Embassy Academy website] brands, with English language tuition being taught alongside a range of "summer courses" such as horse-riding.[http://www.embassyacademy.com/courses/horse-riding Embassy Academy Horse riding page] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150104190425/http://www.embassyacademy.com/courses/horse-riding |date=2015-01-04 }} ==Bellerbys College== {{Main|Bellerbys College}} Bellerbys College is the name of four [[sixth form college]]s for international students in the UK aimed at preparing students for university education. The colleges are located together with Study Group's Embassy schools in: *[[Brighton]] {{coord|50|49|56|N|0|08|27|W}}, *[[Cambridge]], where there are two campuses, Queens Campus {{coord|52|11|44|N|0|07|28|E}} and Manor Campus {{coord|52|13|29|N|0|07|50|E}}, *[[Greenwich]] (London) {{coord|51|28|56|N|0|01|19|W}} and *[[Oxford]] {{coord|51|45|15|N|1|15|28|W}}. *Bellerbys, Oxford has been closed down due to declining business. ==Taylors College== {{Main|Taylors College}} Established in 1920, Taylors College is a university preparation college providing University Foundation, Diploma and Australian [[High School]] programs ([[Year 10]] - [[Year 12]]) in Australia and New Zealand. The Diploma of Commerce program gives students opportunity to enter a range of Degree programs from the second year at the University of Western Australia. Taylors College has four campuses located in the major cities of Australia and New Zealand: [[Melbourne]], [[Sydney]], [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] and [[Auckland]]. ==Charles Sturt University (CSU) Study Centres (Australia)== {{Main|Charles Sturt University Study Centres}} [[Charles Sturt University]] (CSU) is an Australian multi-campus [[public university]] located in [[New South Wales]], [[Queensland]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], and the [[Australian Capital Territory]]. The CSU Study Centres are operated in conjunction with Study Group Australia, offering undergraduate and postgraduate degrees in [[Accounting]], [[Business]] and [[Information Technology]]. It has two campuses located in the city centres of [[Sydney]] and [[Melbourne]], Australia. ==Notable students== According to the Embassy English website, several "celebrities" have studied at various Embassy schools: * [[Ruby Lin]] - Taiwanese actress and singer. Studied English at Embassy New York, with side-classes in acting at the [[New York Film Academy]] in 2004, and wrote a book (''My Private New York'' (2005), Yong Xing Yi Neng, {{ISBN|9867261003}}) about the experience. * [[Katrin Meissner]] - Former freestyle swimmer from East Germany, who won three medals at the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea. * [[Riyo Mori]] - Japanese dance instructor who won the Miss Universe 2007 title in May 2007. She studied at Embassy in New York.{{Citation needed|date=October 2007}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.studygroup.com}} [[Category:Language schools]] [[Category:Multinational companies]] [[Category:International business]] [[Category:Education companies of the United Kingdom]]

{{Infobox spaceflight | name = USA-83 | image = | image_caption = | insignia = | mission_type = [[Navigation satellite|Navigation]] | operator = [[US Air Force]] | COSPAR_ID = 1992-039A{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1992-039A|title=Navstar 2A-05|publisher=US National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=10 July 2012}} | SATCAT = 22014 | mission_duration = 7.5 years (planned) | spacecraft = | spacecraft_type = [[GPS Block IIA]] | manufacturer = [[Rockwell International|Rockwell]] | launch_mass = {{convert|1816|kg}} | dimensions = | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|7 July 1992, 09:20:01|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = {{nowrap|[[Delta II]] 7925-9.5,}} D211 | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|LC-17B]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = | deactivated = {{end-date|5 January 2015}} | orbit_slot = | orbit_epoch = | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Medium Earth orbit|Medium Earth]]
([[Semi-synchronous orbit|Semi-synchronous]]) | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|19959|km}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|20403|km}} | orbit_inclination = 55 degrees | orbit_period = 717.92 minutes | apsis = gee }} '''USA-83''', also known as '''GPS IIA-5''', '''GPS II-14''' and '''GPS SVN-26''', is an [[United States|American]] [[navigation satellite]] which forms part of the [[Global Positioning System]]. It was the fifth of nineteen [[GPS Block IIA|Block IIA]] GPS satellites to be launched. USA-83 was launched at 09:20:01 UTC on 7 July 1992, atop a [[Delta II]] carrier rocket, flight number D211, flying in the 7925-9.5 configuration.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} The launch took place from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|Launch Complex 17B]] at the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]],{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/lvdb/list2.html|title=Launch List|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|work=Launch Vehicle Database|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} and placed USA-83 into a transfer orbit. The satellite raised itself into [[medium Earth orbit]] using a [[Star-37XFP]] [[apogee motor]].{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/navstar-2a.htm|title=GPS-2A (Navstar-2A)|first=Gunter|last=Krebs|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=10 July 2012}} On 6 August 1992, USA-83 was in an orbit with a [[apsis|perigee]] of {{convert|19959|km}}, an [[apsis|apogee]] of {{convert|20403|km}}, a [[orbital period|period]] of 717.92 minutes, and 55 degrees of [[inclination]] to the equator.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/satcat.txt|title=Satellite Catalog|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} It has PRN 26, and operates in slot 2 of plane F of the GPS constellation.{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/project/navstar.htm|title=Navstar|publisher=[[Encyclopedia Astronautica]]|first=Mark|last=Wade|accessdate=10 July 2012}} The satellite has a mass of {{convert|1816|kg}}. It had a design life of 7.5 years; however, it actually remained in service until January 5, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.navcen.uscg.gov/?Do=gpsShowNanu&num=2015005|title=NOTICE ADVISORY TO NAVSTAR USERS (NANU) 2015005|publisher=[[United States Coast Guard]]|accessdate=31 October 2015}} It was subsequently disposed of {{cite web|url=http://gpsworld.com/the-almanac/|title=GPSWorld.com|accessdate=31 October 2015}} and currently resides in a disposal orbit approximately 1000 km above the operational constellation.{{cite web|url=http://www.n2yo.com/satellite/?s=22014|title=N2YO.com|accessdate=31 October 2015}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{GPS satellites}} {{Orbital launches in 1992}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1992]] [[Category:GPS satellites]] [[Category:USA satellites]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}
